content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Daniel Lawson: I was born in Chicago, just a few blocks away from where I live now, which is pretty interesting to think about. I grew up in a working-class neighborhood on the South Side, and my parents both worked hard to make ends meet. They didn't have much in the way of formal education—both only made it through high school—but they were determined to give me and my siblings opportunities they never had. I remember helping my mom with her job at a local diner when I was younger, and my dad worked construction, so I learned early on the value of hard work. I wasn't always sure what I wanted to do with my life, but I knew I wanted to go to college. I got a scholarship to a state school in the Midwest, where I studied political science. It was tough balancing school with work, but I managed to graduate with a bachelor's degree. I've been working full time ever since, and while I'm not where I want to be financially yet, I'm proud of the path I've taken so far.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Daniel Lawson: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about 21, right after I started college, and I had this internship opportunity at a local nonprofit that focused on community development. It was a tough decision because I was also working part-time at a bookstore to help pay for school, and I wasn't sure if I could afford to take the internship without some sort of stipend. But I went for it anyway. That experience opened my eyes to the power of policy and how it affects real people's lives. I realized I didn't just want to study politics—I wanted to be part of the change. That internship led to a job after I graduated, and eventually, it shaped my career path. I think that moment was when I truly started to define who I wanted to be—not just someone who had a degree, but someone who used it to make a difference.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Daniel Lawson: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it didn't feel like one at the time. I remember lying awake at night, thinking about whether I was making the right decision—leaving the bookstore job, taking on the internship without knowing if it would pay off. But I kept coming back to the idea that if I didn't try, I'd always wonder what could have been. I think that's when I realized I had to take control of my own path, even if it meant taking a risk. It wasn't just about the internship itself; it was about deciding that I wanted to be more than just surviving—I wanted to be contributing, to be part of something bigger.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Daniel Lawson: Absolutely, I think I was lucky to have a few people in my life who believed in me when I wasn't sure I believed in myself. My mom, for instance, always encouraged me to think bigger than the circumstances we were in. She'd say things like, 'You're not limited by where you're from, just by what you're willing to work for.' And then there was Mr. Thompson, the director of that nonprofit—I remember how he took a chance on me when I didn't have much to offer except a strong work ethic and a lot of curiosity. He didn't just give me the internship; he gave me a mentorship. I think if I hadn't had those people pushing me, I might have stayed stuck in that cycle of just trying to survive instead of aiming for something more. It's funny how one person's belief in you can change the whole trajectory of your life.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Daniel Lawson: Right now, I'm not in a relationship, and I don't have any children. I've always been focused on my career and personal growth, but I think part of that has to do with the path I've taken. I've had friends who have started families, and I admire their dedication and the way they balance so many responsibilities. For me, I want to make sure that if I do have a family in the future, I can provide them with the kind of stability and opportunities that my parents tried to give me. I'm not in a rush, though. I think relationships take time to build, and I want to be someone who's emotionally present and committed when the time comes. For now, I'm content with my work and the people I care about—my parents, my siblings, and a few close friends who've been there through every step of my journey.

Going through those interview questions brought a lot of clarity to my own journey. Reflecting on my life from childhood to the present, I see how deeply rooted my values are in the lessons I learned growing up—hard work, resilience, and the importance of education. That crossroads moment at 21, taking the internship without knowing if it would pay off, was a turning point. It wasn't just about the opportunity itself, but about the decision to step out of my comfort zone and commit to something bigger than myself. I realize now how much of my path has been shaped by the people who believed in me—my mom, Mr. Thompson, and others who saw potential in me when I couldn't see it myself. As I think about my future, I'm more aware than ever of the balance I want to strike between personal growth and the possibility of family. I want to ensure that if I ever have a family, they have the same opportunities I was given, and I want to be emotionally present for them when the time comes. These reflections have reminded me that my journey, while not easy, has been meaningful and has led me to where I am today.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Daniel Lawson: My immediate family includes my parents and two younger siblings—my sister, Sarah, and my brother, Mark. My parents are still living in the same neighborhood where I grew up, and while things have gotten a little better for them financially, they still work hard every day. My sister is a nurse, and she's always been the more driven one of us. She was the one who encouraged me to apply for that internship when I was 21. My brother, on the other hand, took a different path—he left Chicago after high school and ended up in California, where he works in the tech industry. We don't talk as often as I'd like, but I know he's doing well. My relationship with my parents is pretty close, even though we all have our own lives now. They've always been proud of me, and I try to make sure they know how grateful I am for everything they've done for me. I think family is one of those things that, no matter how much you grow or change, you always come back to.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Daniel Lawson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Jordan, who I met in college. We were in the same political science class, and we bonded over our shared interest in social justice issues. Jordan ended up going into activism, while I took a more policy-oriented path, but we still keep in touch and support each other's work. Then there's Priya, who I met through the nonprofit where I did my internship. She became a close friend and mentor, and even though we're in different parts of the country now, we still have long conversations about our goals and challenges. I think having people like Jordan and Priya in my life has been really important—it's easy to get caught up in your own journey, but having friends who challenge you and remind you of your values makes all the difference. They're the kind of people who make me want to be better, not just in my career, but in how I treat others and the world around me.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Daniel Lawson: I live in a neighborhood on the North Side of Chicago now, just a few blocks from Lake Michigan. It's a pretty diverse area—there are a lot of young professionals, artists, and families who've made it their home. The streets are lined with old brick buildings, some of which have been renovated into cozy apartments or trendy cafes. I like that there's a mix of old and new here, and it feels like a place where people are still building something. I live in a one-bedroom apartment on the third floor of a converted brownstone, and while it's not huge, it's comfortable and has a lot of natural light. I enjoy walking around the neighborhood in the evenings, especially when the weather is nice. There's a small park nearby where I like to sit and read or just people-watch. It's a quiet contrast to the hustle of the city, and I think it's important to have that balance in life—being close to the energy of Chicago but also having a space that feels like home.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Daniel Lawson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. The neighborhood has a strong sense of community, and I've never felt threatened or uncomfortable walking around, even late at night. There are always people out—parents pushing strollers, students coming home from classes, artists setting up their easels in the park. It's not perfect, of course—like anywhere, there are challenges and issues—but I think the sense of mutual respect and shared purpose makes a big difference. I've lived in a few different parts of the city over the years, and this place feels like the kind of neighborhood where people look out for each other. It's not just about safety; it's about feeling like you belong, and that makes all the difference in how secure you feel.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Daniel Lawson: Living here has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On one hand, the cost of living in Chicago is pretty high, especially for someone who's still building their career. I've had to be careful with my budget, and sometimes I feel the pressure of wanting to invest in my future while also enjoying the present. But on the other hand, the culture here is so vibrant. There are always events happening—art shows, community dinners, even political forums that keep me engaged with the issues I care about. I also appreciate how accessible everything is. Whether it's getting a good cup of coffee, finding a bookstore, or just meeting someone for a chat, there's always something going on. I think the biggest thing for me is that this neighborhood has become a kind of second home. It's where I've grown into the person I am today, and I feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself. It's not just a place to live—it's a place where I can dream, reflect, and keep moving forward.

Going through the interview questions about my family, relationships, and neighborhood has made me reflect on how much my personal life and environment shape who I am. Talking about my family reminded me of how grateful I am for their support and how much I want to give back to them in the future. It also made me think about the importance of relationships—whether with family, friends, or the people in my neighborhood—and how they all contribute to a sense of belonging and purpose. Living in my current neighborhood has given me a sense of safety and community that I didn't always have before, and it's become a place where I feel like I can truly be myself. These reflections have made me more aware of how interconnected my personal life and environment are, and how they both play a role in my ongoing journey of growth and self-discovery.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Daniel Lawson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but there's also a lot of flexibility depending on work and personal goals. I start most mornings around 7 or 8, usually with a cup of coffee and some time to read or listen to a podcast—something that helps me get my mind focused for the day. I work full time at a nonprofit that focuses on urban development, so my days are pretty consistent in terms of hours, though the work itself can vary a lot. Some days are spent in meetings, others in the field working with community groups, and sometimes I'm just buried in reports or grant proposals. I try to make time for exercise, usually a run or a gym session in the evenings, and I've gotten into the habit of cooking most nights instead of eating out. On the weekends, I like to take it easy—maybe catch up with friends, visit my parents, or just spend time in the neighborhood. I also try to set aside some time for personal projects, like learning a new skill or reading a book that's been on my list for a while. It's not always perfect, but I think having that balance between work, personal growth, and connection with others is what keeps me grounded.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Daniel Lawson: I work full time at a nonprofit organization called 'Chicago Futures,' which focuses on urban development and community empowerment. My role is in policy and program coordination, so I spend a lot of time working with local leaders, community groups, and government agencies to design and implement initiatives that help underprivileged neighborhoods thrive. I work Monday through Friday, typically from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., though there are days when I stay late to meet with stakeholders or prepare for upcoming projects. I've been in this position for about three years now, and it's been incredibly rewarding to see the impact of our work on the ground. Whether it's helping a neighborhood secure funding for a new community center or supporting local entrepreneurs with resources and training, I feel like I'm contributing to something meaningful. It's not always easy work—there are challenges, red tape, and setbacks—but I remind myself that change takes time, and every small step forward matters.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Daniel Lawson: Outside of work, I also have a few routines that help me stay grounded. Every Sunday evening, I try to set my goals for the week—whether it's a professional task, a personal project, or just something simple like reading a chapter of a book. I also make it a point to volunteer at least once a month, usually at a local food pantry or community center. It's a way for me to give back, and it reminds me of the support I received when I was younger. I also have a habit of journaling, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed or trying to process something important. It's not always easy to put my thoughts into words, but I find that it helps me clarify my feelings and stay focused on what truly matters. And, of course, I try to stay in touch with my family and friends, even if it's just a quick call or a text. I think those small, consistent habits are what keep me balanced and connected to the people and values that matter most.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Daniel Lawson: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness into my mornings. I started practicing meditation a few months ago after a particularly stressful project at work, and it's made a noticeable difference in how I approach the day. I used to rush out the door, barely having time to eat breakfast, but now I take 15 minutes to sit quietly, breathe, and set an intention for the day. It's not perfect—some mornings I still feel rushed—but it's helped me feel more centered, especially with everything going on in the city and in my work. I also started taking a different route to work, one that goes through a quieter part of the neighborhood where I can walk past the community garden. It's a small change, but it's given me a chance to slow down and notice things I might have otherwise missed. I think it's important to find little ways to reconnect with yourself, especially when life gets busy.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Daniel Lawson: I don't have children yet, but I've spent a lot of time thinking about what a typical day might look like for them if I did. I imagine waking up early, maybe around 7 a.m., with a calm and structured morning routine—something that includes breakfast, a little quiet time for reading or drawing, and then getting ready for school. I'd want them to have a strong foundation in education, so I'd make sure they attended a school that emphasized both academics and creativity. After school, I'd hope they'd have time for activities they're passionate about—maybe something like music, sports, or community service. I think it's important for kids to explore their interests and build confidence through experiences outside the classroom. Of course, I'd also want to make sure they had time to just be kids, to play, to be with friends, and to have moments of unstructured joy. If I ever have children, I want them to grow up knowing they're loved, supported, and encouraged to dream big—just like I was.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 has made me reflect on how deeply my personal life, relationships, and environment shape who I am and where I'm headed. Talking about my family reminded me of how grateful I am for their support and how much I want to give back to them in the future. It also made me think about the importance of relationships—whether with family, friends, or the people in my neighborhood—and how they all contribute to a sense of belonging and purpose. Living in my current neighborhood has given me a sense of safety and community that I didn't always have before, and it's become a place where I feel like I can truly be myself. These reflections have made me more aware of how interconnected my personal life and environment are, and how they both play a role in my ongoing journey of growth and self-discovery. My daily routines, responsibilities, and the balance I try to maintain between work, personal growth, and connection with others are all part of this journey. I'm learning that it's not just about where I live or what I do for a living—it's about how I engage with the world and the people in it. I want to continue growing, not just professionally, but as a person who is grounded, connected, and committed to making a difference in the lives of others, just as those who supported me did for me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Daniel Lawson: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—helping my dad with construction work, running around the neighborhood with my siblings, that kind of thing. I've made a conscious effort to keep that up as an adult, so I try to run at least three to four times a week, and I go to the gym a couple of times if my schedule allows. I've also been pretty mindful about my diet, mostly because I've seen how stress and poor eating habits can take a toll on your energy and focus. I try to eat balanced meals, and I've cut down on processed foods and sugar over the years. That said, I'm not perfect—I do have my off days, especially when work gets overwhelming. I've also dealt with some anxiety from time to time, especially during high-pressure projects or when I'm trying to balance a lot of responsibilities. But I've been working on managing that through meditation, journaling, and talking to friends I trust. I think it's important to take care of your mental health just as much as your physical health, and I've learned that small, consistent habits make a big difference over time.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Daniel Lawson: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that I can rely on—like my morning runs or the gym sessions I fit in when I can. I also find that being around people who care about their well-being, like my friends Jordan and Priya, keeps me motivated. They're always encouraging each other to stay active or try new healthy habits. What makes it harder, though, is the stress that comes with work and the pressure to constantly be productive. There are days when I feel like I don't have time to take care of myself, and I end up skipping a workout or grabbing fast food instead of cooking. I've learned that it's not about being perfect—it's about showing up for yourself even on the tough days. I think the biggest challenge is balancing the demands of work and life without losing sight of the fact that taking care of my health is the foundation for everything else I want to achieve.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Daniel Lawson: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some persistent lower back pain, which I think is related to the long hours I spend sitting at my desk, especially during those late nights working on grant proposals or reports. I didn't think much of it at first—just dismissed it as something I could work through with stretching or a few days off. But then, about a year ago, I started experiencing sharp pain that radiated down my leg, which made me realize I needed to take it more seriously. I finally went to a physical therapist, and it turned out to be a herniated disc. It was a bit of a wake-up call for me. I had to adjust my posture, start incorporating more core-strengthening exercises into my routine, and set boundaries around my work hours to give my body a chance to heal. It's been a process, but I'm much better now. I've also started using a standing desk and taking more breaks throughout the day to move around. It's funny how something that seemed so minor at first could have such a big impact on your daily life. I've learned that taking care of your body isn't just about staying in shape—it's about listening to it and making changes when it needs them.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Daniel Lawson: Honestly, the back issue did make things a bit more challenging, especially with the long hours I put in at work. There were days when I had to push through the pain just to get things done, and I worried it might affect my performance or even my ability to keep up with the demands of my job. But what I realized was that taking care of my health wasn't just about avoiding pain—it was about being able to show up fully for the work I care about and for the people I love. I had to make some changes, like setting clearer boundaries between work and rest, and I've been more intentional about taking breaks throughout the day. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that my health is the foundation of everything else. If I don't take care of myself, I can't be the best version of who I want to be for my family, my community, or even for myself.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Daniel Lawson: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of growth and reflection. There's been a lot of personal development, both professionally and in how I approach my own well-being. I've started to feel more grounded in my work at Chicago Futures, and I've taken on more leadership responsibilities, which has been both challenging and rewarding. At the same time, I've been more intentional about my health, especially after dealing with the back issues. It's taught me the importance of balance—not just between work and rest, but also between pushing forward and knowing when to pause and take care of myself. I've also been thinking a lot about the future, especially in terms of relationships and family. I'm not in a rush, but I've started to feel more clarity about what I want out of life beyond my career. I want to be someone who not only makes a difference in their community but also builds meaningful connections and creates a life that feels full and authentic. It's been a year of learning, adjusting, and growing into the person I want to be.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 has made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits influence my overall well-being and ability to engage with the world around me. Talking about my health reminded me of how important it is to listen to my body and make adjustments when needed—like when I dealt with the back pain and learned to incorporate more movement and mindfulness into my routine. It also made me think about how easy it is to neglect self-care when life gets busy, but how essential it is to show up for myself even on the hardest days. Incorporating mindfulness into my mornings and taking small steps to stay active have become part of my identity now, and I've come to see them not just as routines, but as acts of self-respect. I've also realized that my mental health is just as important as my physical health, and that finding balance between work, rest, and personal growth is key to living a full and meaningful life. These reflections have reminded me that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a foundation for everything else I want to achieve, whether in my career, relationships, or community.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Daniel Lawson: I think I've struggled with anxiety from time to time, especially during high-pressure periods at work or when I'm trying to balance a lot of responsibilities. There were moments, especially in my early 20s, when I felt like I was constantly trying to prove myself—whether it was in school, in my job, or in my personal life. I remember feeling overwhelmed during that internship at the nonprofit, not just because of the workload, but because I was afraid of failing or not living up to the expectations I had for myself. It took me a while to realize that anxiety doesn't always mean I'm doing something wrong—it can be a sign that I'm pushing myself to grow, but I also need to learn how to slow down and breathe. Over the past few years, I've been working on managing that through meditation, journaling, and talking to people I trust. I've come to see anxiety not as something to fear, but as a part of life that I can navigate with awareness and care.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Daniel Lawson: For my family, it's been a year of quiet resilience and support. My parents have always been the kind of people who don't talk much about their struggles, but I can see how much they've been holding up under their own pressures. My mom still works at the diner, though she's started taking on more shifts to help with some medical bills, and my dad has been dealing with some health issues of his own—nothing too serious, but enough to slow him down a bit. They've always been proud of me, even when I was struggling to find my path, and I think that pride has been a source of strength for them too. My sister, Sarah, has been going through a tough time at work with the nursing shortage and the stress of the pandemic, but she's been handling it with grace and determination. My brother, Mark, hasn't been around as much as I'd like, but I know he's been busy with his job and his own family. I think what's been most important for all of us is knowing that we're still connected, even when life gets complicated. We've had a few family dinners lately, and it's been nice to just sit and talk without the pressure of everything else. I feel lucky to have them in my life, and I hope I can be there for them in the same way they've always been there for me.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Daniel Lawson: For me, religion or spirituality hasn't been a big part of my life, though I respect the role it plays for others. Growing up, my family wasn't particularly religious, and I never felt the need to fill that space with anything formal. I think I've always leaned more into the idea of personal meaning—like the values I was raised with: hard work, resilience, and caring for others. I don't think of it as spirituality in the traditional sense, but I do believe in the importance of connection—whether it's with people, the world around me, or even the quiet moments of reflection that help me feel grounded. I've never felt the need to label it, but I do think about how my actions impact those around me, and that sense of responsibility has always been a guiding force in my life. I guess I see it more as a personal philosophy than a formal belief system.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Daniel Lawson: I use social media more for staying connected with friends and colleagues than for following the wider world. I have a Facebook account where I keep in touch with my family and old friends from college, and I follow a few pages related to urban development and social justice, which are topics I care about. I don't use Instagram much, but I do check it occasionally to see what friends are up to or to follow some local artists in the neighborhood. I think social media can be a useful tool for staying informed and connected, but I also try to be mindful of how much time I spend on it. I've noticed that when I'm too caught up in scrolling through news or comparing my life to others, it can affect my mood. So I've started setting limits—like not checking my phone first thing in the morning or before bed. It's not about avoiding social media entirely, but about using it in a way that supports my well-being rather than detracts from it. I think it's all about balance, just like everything else in life.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Daniel Lawson: Honestly, I haven't relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, the support I've needed has mostly come from the people I know in real life—my family, friends, or even coworkers who I trust. That said, I have used Facebook a few times to reach out to people in my community who might have advice or resources, especially when I was first starting out in my career. I remember posting a question about local grants for community projects, and a few people responded with leads or contacts that were really helpful. It wasn't a substitute for real support, but it showed me that even online connections can be a starting point. I think the key is knowing when to turn to others, whether online or in person, and being open to the help that comes your way.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 has made me reflect on how deeply my health and mental well-being are intertwined with the rest of my life. Talking about my back pain and the adjustments I had to make reminded me that taking care of my body isn't just about staying in shape—it's about listening to it and making changes when it needs them. It also made me think about how anxiety has been a part of my journey, especially during high-pressure times, and how I've learned to manage it through mindfulness, journaling, and leaning on the people I trust. I've come to see anxiety not as something to fear, but as a part of life that I can navigate with awareness and care. These reflections have reinforced the idea that my health—both physical and mental—is the foundation for everything else I want to achieve, whether in my career, relationships, or personal growth. I'm learning that it's not about perfection, but about showing up for myself and making choices that support my well-being, even on the hardest days.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Daniel Lawson: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have been more manageable, largely because I've been more intentional about how I handle challenges. I used to let work-related stress build up until it became overwhelming, but now I try to address it earlier—whether that means talking to a colleague, taking a walk, or just stepping away for a few minutes to breathe. I've also been more open about my feelings with the people I trust, which has made a big difference. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but I've learned that vulnerability isn't a weakness—it's a way of connecting and growing. I've started journaling more regularly, not just for reflection, but as a way to process my emotions and track my progress. It's helped me see patterns in how I respond to stress and what truly helps me cope. I'm not saying I don't still have tough days, but I feel more equipped to handle them now. It's like I've built a little toolkit for emotional resilience, and I'm learning to use it more often.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Daniel Lawson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is the largest chunk—my apartment on the North Side is pretty standard for the area, but it still takes up about a third of my income. Groceries have been a bit tight lately, especially with the cost of living rising, but I've been trying to meal prep more to stretch my budget. I also have a monthly car payment for my sedan, which I use to commute to work and run errands. Public transportation is an option, but I find it less reliable for my schedule. I also set aside money for utilities, insurance, and a small emergency fund. I've been trying to be more mindful of my spending, especially with the back pain issue—I've been investing in a few ergonomic tools for my workspace and some physical therapy sessions. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I try to prioritize what truly matters, like my health and the ability to keep contributing to my work and community.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Daniel Lawson: Last month, my household spending was a bit higher than usual, mostly because I had to cover some unexpected expenses related to my back therapy and a few new ergonomic tools for my workspace. On average, though, I usually spend around $2,500 to $2,700 a month. That breaks down to about $1,200 for rent, $600 for groceries and utilities, $400 for my car payment and gas, and the rest goes toward insurance, savings, and occasional personal expenses like books or a coffee out with friends. I try to keep my budget as tight as possible, but I also make sure to set aside a little for things that bring me joy or help me recharge—like a weekend walk by the lake or a good book. It's not always perfect, but I think being mindful of where my money goes helps me stay grounded and focused on what truly matters.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Daniel Lawson: We rent our home. I live in a one-bedroom apartment on the North Side, which I've been in for about two years now. Renting has always made more sense for me, especially given my career stage and the uncertainty that comes with any job in the nonprofit sector. I don't see myself buying a home anytime soon—there's just too much to consider, and I want to make sure I'm in a stable place financially before making such a big commitment. Plus, I like the flexibility of renting; it allows me to be close to the city's energy while still having a space that feels like home. I know some of my friends have bought homes, and I admire their dedication, but for now, renting works for me.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Daniel Lawson: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, mostly tied to the seasons and my work schedule. In the winter, heating costs went up a bit, which I didn't expect since I thought my apartment was pretty well insulated. I also had to pay for a few months of physical therapy for my back, which added to my expenses. Then there were the holidays—like Thanksgiving and Christmas—when I spent a little more on groceries and a small gift for my parents. On the flip side, summer was a bit easier on the budget because I didn't need to heat the apartment as much, and I was able to save a little more by eating out less. I also noticed that my transportation costs fluctuated depending on how often I had to travel for work meetings or volunteer projects. Overall, I've been trying to track my spending more closely, especially with the rising cost of living, and I've made a point to adjust my habits when needed—like cooking at home more or using public transit when I can. It's not always easy to stay on top of it all, but I think being aware of how my expenses shift throughout the year helps me plan better and stay in control of my finances.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 has made me reflect on how deeply connected my family and my well-being are, and how even small moments of support can make a big difference. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've been through and how their resilience has always been a source of strength for me. It also made me think about how I've leaned on them throughout my life, and how I want to be there for them in return. I've come to realize that while I may not rely on social media for emotional support, the real connections I have with the people I care about are what truly help me navigate tough times. These reflections have reinforced the idea that family, community, and real-life relationships are the foundation of my emotional resilience, and that I'm lucky to have such a strong support system in my life.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Daniel Lawson: I do have a savings account, and I try to save consistently, even if it's just a small amount each month. I set aside about $100 to $150 every paycheck, which goes into a separate account that I don't touch unless it's for something truly necessary, like an emergency or a planned purchase. I think it's important to have that financial cushion, especially in a city like Chicago where things can change quickly. I also try to save for specific goals—like a trip I've been wanting to take to see some of the community projects I've worked on in other parts of the country, or maybe even a future home down the line. I'm not great at saving large sums, but I've learned that even small, regular contributions add up over time. It's not about having a lot—it's about having a sense of security and knowing that I'm working toward something, even if it's just a little at a time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Daniel Lawson: In the last year, I've been saving more with a focus on both short-term and long-term goals. On the short-term side, I've been building up an emergency fund to cover unexpected expenses, like the physical therapy I needed for my back or any sudden car repairs. I know how quickly things can come up, especially in a city like Chicago, and I want to make sure I'm not caught off guard. On the long-term side, I've been saving for a future home, though I'm not in a rush. I think it's important to have that goal in mind, even if it's a ways off. I also save for personal growth—like courses I want to take or books that inspire me. I've found that having these different savings goals helps me stay motivated and focused on the future, even when the present feels a bit uncertain. It's not about having everything figured out, but about taking small, consistent steps toward something bigger.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Daniel Lawson: My occupation is as a policy and program coordinator at a nonprofit organization called 'Chicago Futures,' which focuses on urban development and community empowerment. In this role, I work closely with local leaders, community groups, and government agencies to design and implement initiatives that help underprivileged neighborhoods thrive. The most important activities include conducting needs assessments, developing policy proposals, and coordinating community engagement efforts. I also spend a lot of time in the field, meeting with residents to understand their challenges and aspirations. One of the most rewarding parts of my job is seeing the impact of our work—whether it's helping a neighborhood secure funding for a new community center or supporting local entrepreneurs with resources and training. It's not always easy work—there are challenges, red tape, and setbacks—but I remind myself that change takes time, and every small step forward matters. I think what keeps me motivated is knowing that I'm contributing to something meaningful, and that my work helps create opportunities for people who might not have had them otherwise.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Daniel Lawson: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the projects we're working on. Some weeks are more structured, with clear start and end times, while others require staying late to meet deadlines or attend meetings with stakeholders. I've learned to be flexible with my schedule, especially since a lot of our work involves collaboration with community groups and local leaders, which can sometimes require meeting outside of regular office hours. I also find that I'm often thinking about work even when I'm not at my desk, which is why I've made it a point to set boundaries—like not checking emails after a certain time or taking weekends off whenever possible. It's a balance, but one I've come to accept as part of the job. What keeps me going is knowing that the time I invest in this work is helping create real change in people's lives, and that makes the long hours feel more meaningful.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Daniel Lawson: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on one role at a time, especially since my work at Chicago Futures requires a lot of dedication and collaboration. I did take on some part-time evening work during my first few years out of college, mostly to help cover expenses while I was still figuring out my career path. But once I landed this position, I realized how important it was to be fully present for the work I was doing. I didn't want to spread myself too thin or compromise the quality of what I was contributing. Plus, with the demands of policy work and community engagement, I've found that having a single, focused role allows me to be more effective and intentional in how I show up for the people and communities we serve. I think that's why I've always been okay with the longer hours—it's not about working more, but about working with purpose.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 has made me reflect on how my emotional well-being and financial stability are deeply connected to the people and habits that support me. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how important it is to address challenges early, rather than letting them build up until they become overwhelming. It also made me think about how my relationships with family and friends are a cornerstone of my emotional resilience—knowing I can lean on them when things get tough gives me a sense of security that no amount of money or planning can replace. At the same time, reflecting on my monthly budget and how I manage my finances has made me more aware of the balance I need to strike between practicality and personal fulfillment. I've come to see that taking care of my mental health and maintaining a stable financial foundation are both essential parts of living a meaningful life. These reflections have reinforced the idea that I'm not just working toward a career or a future home—I'm working toward a life that feels grounded, connected, and full of purpose.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Daniel Lawson: In terms of income, my household made around $4,200 last month. That's from my full-time salary at Chicago Futures, which is pretty standard for someone in my role. I don't have any other sources of income right now, and I've been careful not to take on extra work that might compromise the quality of what I do. I know it's not a huge amount, especially in a city like Chicago, but it's enough to cover my expenses and still set aside some money for savings and personal growth. I've been trying to be more mindful of how I spend and where I can cut back without sacrificing what truly matters—like my health, my community work, and the ability to keep learning and growing. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm on the right track.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Daniel Lawson: I've been at Chicago Futures for about three years now, and it's been a really formative experience. The benefits package is pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance, dental, and vision coverage, which is a big relief, especially with the back issues I've had to deal with. We also get a generous amount of paid time off, which I've come to appreciate more as I've learned the importance of rest and self-care. I have about 20 days of vacation each year, and I try to use at least a few of them to take short trips or just step away from the city for a bit. Sick time is also something I've found useful, especially when I'm dealing with flare-ups of my back pain or just need a day to recharge. What I like most about the benefits is that they support not just my work, but my overall well-being, which I think is essential for being able to show up fully for the people and communities we serve.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Daniel Lawson: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, Alex, who's been a huge support throughout my time here. He's someone who leads with empathy and really values the input of the team. We've had some tough projects together, but he's always been open to feedback and willing to adjust our approach when needed. As for my coworkers, I think we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We're all working toward the same goal—making a real difference in people's lives—and that shared purpose creates a kind of bond. I've formed some really meaningful friendships with a few of them, especially with someone like Priya, who I mentioned earlier. She's been a mentor to me in many ways, and I look up to her both professionally and personally. I think the key to our good relationships is that we all care deeply about the work we do, and that shared passion makes it easier to collaborate, support each other, and keep going even when things get tough.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Daniel Lawson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there's some flexibility depending on the projects we're working on. Most days, I start around 8:30 a.m. and finish by 5:00 p.m., but there are times when I need to stay late to wrap up a report or meet with a community group. I also have some flexibility in how I structure my day—like if I need to leave early for a doctor's appointment or take a walk during lunch to clear my head. That said, I've learned that while flexibility is a good thing, it also means I have to be disciplined about setting boundaries. I try to avoid working late unless it's absolutely necessary, and I make it a point to take weekends off whenever possible. I think the predictability of the schedule helps me plan better, especially when it comes to balancing work with personal goals, like saving for the future or staying active. It's not perfect, but it's a rhythm I've come to rely on.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Daniel Lawson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is stable enough to meet my needs and support my goals, but there's definitely room for growth. I'm not where I want to be in terms of wealth, but I'm proud of how I've managed to build a life that allows me to contribute meaningfully to my community and take care of myself. I know that financial security is something that takes time, especially in a city like Chicago where the cost of living is high, but I'm trying to be intentional about my spending and savings. I want to make sure that if I ever have a family, I can provide them with the kind of opportunities I was given, and I'm working toward that step by step. It's not about having a lot—it's about having enough to live with purpose and give back, and I think I'm on the right path.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 has made me reflect on how my financial stability and emotional well-being are deeply intertwined with the rhythms of my life. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of being mindful and adaptable with my budget, especially as unexpected expenses like physical therapy or seasonal changes can impact my finances. It also made me think about how my work schedule and the flexibility it offers help me manage these fluctuations—whether it's adjusting my spending habits or finding small ways to save. At the same time, reflecting on my savings goals and how I allocate my income has reinforced the idea that financial security isn't just about having a lot, but about making intentional choices that support both my present and future. I've come to see that managing my money is not just a practical task—it's a way of honoring the values I hold, like resilience, responsibility, and the desire to contribute meaningfully to my community. These reflections have reminded me that while I may not be wealthy, I'm building a life that feels grounded, purposeful, and aligned with who I want to be.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Daniel Lawson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom worked at a local diner, and my dad was a construction worker. They both worked long hours, often coming home tired but always making sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. I remember my mom working nights sometimes, especially when the diner was busy, and my dad would be out on job sites from early morning until late afternoon. It wasn't easy, but they never complained. They always made it clear that their work was about providing for us and giving us a chance at something better. I think that's where I got my strong work ethic from—seeing them sacrifice so much just to give me and my siblings opportunities they never had. It also made me appreciate the value of hard work and the importance of using your skills to support others, which is something I carry with me in my career today.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Daniel Lawson: My mom worked as a waitress at a diner on the South Side, and my dad was a construction worker, mostly doing residential projects. Their most important activities were making sure we had meals on the table, paying the bills, and providing a stable environment for us to grow up in. My mom's days were long—she'd start early in the morning, sometimes before dawn, to get ready for her shift. She'd work until late at night, especially on weekends when the diner was busy. I remember her coming home exhausted but always making time to talk to us, to listen to our day, and to make sure we felt heard. My dad's work was more physically demanding. He'd be out on job sites from sunrise to sunset, sometimes longer, depending on the project. He'd come home with calloused hands and a tired look, but he always had a smile for us. He'd talk about the work he was doing, the people he met, and the progress being made. Both of them had their own ways of showing love and support, and I think that's where I learned the value of hard work—not just for yourself, but for the people you care about. Their work wasn't glamorous, but it was meaningful, and it taught me that even the most ordinary jobs can be the foundation for something bigger.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Daniel Lawson: My mom worked at a diner called 'The Blue Plate,' which was a small, family-owned business on the South Side. It was one of those places where everyone knew your name, and the regulars would stop by just to chat with the staff. The diner was open from early morning until late at night, and my mom worked some of those late shifts, especially on weekends when the place was packed. She made sure we always had meals on the table, even when money was tight. My dad worked for a construction company that specialized in residential projects—building homes, fixing up apartments, that kind of thing. He was part of a crew that worked on different sites, and he had to be pretty versatile, doing everything from laying foundations to finishing touches. He always said that construction was about more than just building structures—it was about creating spaces where people could live, grow, and feel safe. Both of them worked hard, not just for themselves, but for us, and I think that's where I learned the value of work—not just as a means to an end, but as a way to build something meaningful for others.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Daniel Lawson: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still in this line of work, but with more influence and impact. I want to be in a position where I can lead initiatives that truly transform communities, not just support them from the sidelines. I also hope I'm more financially stable, not because I want luxury, but because I want the freedom to focus on what matters most—my work, my health, and the people I care about. I hope I'm still living in this neighborhood, still walking by the lake, still feeling connected to the rhythm of the city. And I hope, if the right person comes along, I'm ready to build a family with someone who shares my values and my vision for the future. I want to be someone who not only makes a difference in their own life but also helps others find their path, just like the people who helped me when I was starting out. That's the kind of future I'm working toward—one that's grounded, purposeful, and full of possibility.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Daniel Lawson: What I value the most in my life is connection—both with people and with the world around me. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of work and the pressures of daily life, but what keeps me grounded is the relationships I have with my family, my friends, and the community I'm part of. I value the moments when I can sit down with my parents and just talk, or when I'm out in the neighborhood and see someone I know wave from across the street. I also value the work I do because it gives me a sense of purpose—it's not just about a paycheck, but about contributing to something bigger than myself. I think the most important thing I've learned is that life isn't just about achieving goals or climbing the ladder; it's about being present, being kind, and making sure that the people around you feel seen and supported. I want to live a life that reflects those values, and I hope that, in the end, I can look back and know that I showed up for the things that truly matter.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 has made me reflect on how my financial stability, work environment, and relationships at work all play a role in shaping my sense of purpose and well-being. Talking about my income and monthly budget reminded me of the importance of being mindful with my money, especially as I work toward long-term goals like saving for a home or ensuring I can provide for a future family. It also made me think about how my job at Chicago Futures isn't just about the work itself, but about the support I receive from my employer—like health benefits, paid time off, and a sense of community with my coworkers. I've come to see that having a stable income and a supportive workplace are both essential for living a life that feels meaningful and balanced. My relationships with my manager and coworkers have also reinforced the idea that work doesn't have to be isolating—it can be a place where I grow, connect with others, and feel valued. These reflections have reminded me that while I may not have everything figured out, I'm building a life that aligns with my values: purpose, connection, and the ability to contribute to something bigger than myself.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me. It has allowed me to look back on my childhood, my struggles, my choices, and the people who have shaped me, and see how each piece has contributed to who I am today. I never imagined that the simple act of helping my mom at the diner or the decision to take that internship at 21 would lead me to where I am now—working in a field that aligns with my values and gives me a sense of purpose. This process has reminded me of how interconnected my past, present, and future are, and how much my family, friends, and community have played a role in my growth. It has also made me more aware of the importance of balance—between work and rest, between personal goals and relationships, and between self-care and contribution to others. I've come to see that my life story isn't just a series of events, but a tapestry of choices, support, and resilience that continues to evolve. I'm grateful for this reflection, not just for the clarity it has brought, but for the reminder that I am still in the process of becoming, and that every step I take—no matter how small—is part of a meaningful journey.
